message:
I googled a lot before posting here but I didn't find what I'm searching for. I need some recommendations for books about architecture in general. Most of the books that I found are old and I guess will be outdated. Web servers, Caching, In-memory stores, Key value stores,  Proxies, Load balancers, Message queues, Sharding and Replication of stores. I'm really interested in this kind of posts : https://github.com/blog/530-how-we-made-github-fast & http://highscalability.com/blog/2011/3/3/stack-overflow-architecture-update-now-at-95-million-page-vi.html . The idea of thinking of and architecturing highly scalable systems and the design patterns used. Maybe what I'm asking for is too much for a single book but at least you got my point. I'd be really thankful if you could recommend some books or even the proper search keywords. Thank you.
EDIT: The closest to what I'm searching for was "Service-Oriented design with Ruby and Rails" ( http://www.amazon.com/Service-Oriented-Design-Addison-Wesley-Professional-Series/dp/0321659368 ) it contains chapters about Load balancing, caching and messaging.

data.message: If you really wanna learn about arquitecture there are two books that you have to read and understand : http://www.amazon.com/Patterns-Enterprise-Application-Architecture-Martin/dp/0321127420 and http://www.amazon.es/Domain-Driven-Design-Tackling-Complexity-Software/dp/0321125215 . These are fundemental books to understand good software arquitecture.

Thank you for the books. I'll sure give them a try. But I have a question that may sound silly. When reading about architecture specially the kind of architecture I mentioned in the post, Shouldn't I be reading book that are published after maybe ~2009 or something ?
Something exactly like this one ( http://www.cloudcomputingpatterns.org/ ) but honestly it's too expensive :D

Hi Muhammad Bassem, I understand what you mean and we, our-self, had the same impression you have now, but these books  are a must read because they are the basis of what "modern" enterprise architecture is. I encourage you to follow the authors' blogs because they are considered ones of the best software architects in the world till now.

By the way, if you are really interested in Enterprise Architecture, let me add this book to close the circle: http://www.amazon.com/Enterprise-Integration-Patterns-Designing-Deploying/dp/0321200683/ref=sr_1_sc_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1424247909&sr=1-1-spell&keywords=eterprise+integration+pattern and its website: http://www.enterpriseintegrationpatterns.com/ .
